awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Vulnerabilities in Critical Global Trade Infrastructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific interest in infrastructure has tried to understand the mechanical, human, and natural forces that impact the flow of information and services. These infrastructures have become increasingly dependent on the global movement of goods and peoples. The global systems that deliver these resources, however, are inevitably funneled through bottlenecks or "chokepoints", such as canals, tunnels, maritime straights, border crossings, etc. Constricting the flow of materials and people, such chokepoints are both vital to national and economic interests, and uniquely vulnerable, dynamic, and prone to disturbances. Not surprisingly, governments, corporations, and communities have taken a keen interest in securing and regulating these sites. Little is known, however, about how these passageways actually work. This collaborative project seeks to explore how local communities, environments, and infrastructures interact to allow passage through these sites (or not), as well how ordinary (and sometimes extraordinary) events at chokepoints affect economic systems, security, and lives well beyond these points of passage.

Christopher Middleton and Gabriela Valdivia of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Ashley Carse of Vanderbilt University, Jatin Dua of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, Elizabeth Dunn of Indiana University, and Jason Cons of the University of Texas at Austin, will explore six chokepoints around the world. Each member of the team is an expert in their region of study. Each will focus on a particular kind of chokepoint. These include: the Panama Canal, a tunnel in Russia, a land bridge in India, an oil-refinery and pipelines in Ecuador, a network of rivers in Bangladesh, and a maritime strait leading into the Red Sea. The researchers will utilize extensive interviews, observation, and first-person engagement with officials, workers, and chokepoint residents in order to understand the distinctly human dimensions of these transit zones. Bringing together data from around the world, this study will provide a strategic reassessment of the global movement of goods, information, and people by examining these vital and dynamic points of national and world interest. The results will speak directly to current concerns over migration, security, and economic wellbeing.  In doing so, this project promises to alter the ways governments, industries, and others understand and engage with these critical transit points of the world today.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project brought together social scientists from multiple universities to investigate Vulnerabilities in Critical Global Trade Infrastructures. The project's theoretical and empirical focus was chokepoints: sites where the movement of information, people, or goods is constricted. The centrality of international trade and global supply chains to everyday life makes chokepoints sites of vital public interest as well as strategic and commercial importance. Not surprisingly, governments, militaries, corporations, and communities have taken a keen interest in securing and regulating these sites. Yet little is known about how these passageways actually work, how peoples, environments, and infrastructure interact to allow passage through these sites (or not), and how dynamics at these bottlenecks are reshaping life at--and ultimately far beyond--their points of passage. The six ethnographers involved in this project conducted research globally at a number of key chokepoints—shipping lanes, canals, tunnels, lanes, pipelines, riverine deltas, and geopolitical corridors— to advance knowledge of how global trade and transport relate to local social, political, and economic issues.

Jatin Dua, one of the principal investigators, conducted research on shipping lanes and projects of port-making in the Bab-el-Mandeb region at the maritime crossroads of Asia and Africa. Based on ethnographic fieldwork conducted onboard cargo ships as they transited from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean, as well engaging a variety of stakeholders in port cities in the Horn of Africa and the Arabian Gulf, Dua’s research highlights the key role played by shipping in shaping political, social and economic life in this region. Some 90 percent of global trade, approximately six billion tons of cargo, travels on the over 100,000 cargo ships that are operated by 1.25 million seafarers. Almost everything we eat, wear or otherwise consume on a daily basis has some connection to these vessels and global shipping. The Bab-el-Mandeb is a central hub in this global shipping economy. Between 22,000 and 25,000 vessels transit through the Suez Canal each year and every day 3.3 million barrels of oil are transported through the Bab el Mandeb Strait. In addition to being vital to economic life in the region, Dua's research emphasizes the salience of shipping and port-making in this region as both peril and possibility. Chokepoints such as straits and ports are places of new political possibilities and highlight the power of circulation to transform the very orders that channel and regulate flow.

Intellectual merit outcomes of Dua's research included: A) publishing single-author and multi-author articles in peer-reviewed journals; B) presenting research and organizing panels at the meetings of the American Anthropological Association; Law and Society Association; Association for Asian Studies and International Conference on Asian Studies C) giving guest lectures and keynote lectures at universities in the United States, Europe, Asia and Africa; D) contributing to special issues on the project theme of "Chokepoints", including one written for the public and one written for a scholarly audience. 

Broader impacts outcomes of Dua's research included: A) writing and engaging public audiences through public facing writing such as blog posts, participating in public roundtables and being interviewed for radio programs and podcasts in United States, Netherlands, Somalia, and Austria; B) disseminating information about the Bab-el-Mandeb to a policy audience through writing and engaging policy experts in the United States; C) providing training for four doctoral student at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor.

Through the development of a comparative and global framework this project accordingly has sought to understand the hitherto hidden and human dimensions of global chokepoints. In doing so, this project fosters a more thorough understanding of how these sites work, for whom, and how they impart critical opportunities--and vulnerabilities--to global trade infrastructures.
